name: National Palace of Sintra
tagline: Portugal's oldest palace with over 1000 years of history

description.short: Located in the heart of Sintra village and spanning over 1000 years of Portuguese history, the National Palace of Sintra is one of the oldest palaces in Portugal, instantly recognizable by its two iconic conical chimneys.
description.full: The National Palace of Sintra emerges from many centuries of royal construction and adaptation, making it a unique architectural ensemble that spans the entire history of Portugal. The palace's origins likely date back to the 10th or 11th century during Moorish rule. At the end of the Middle Ages, it became one of the preferred destinations for Portuguese monarchs, who were drawn by abundant hunting, the cool summer climate, and the need for refuge during plague outbreaks in Lisbon. The palace features remarkable rooms including the Swan Room, Magpie Room, and the spectacular Coats of Arms Room with its domed ceiling displaying the heraldic shields of 72 noble Portuguese families. The iconic twin conical chimneys, rising 33 meters above the royal kitchen, have become the symbol of Sintra. The palace showcases various architectural styles from different periods, including Moorish, Gothic, and Manueline elements, with stunning azulejo tilework throughout. Today, it houses an exceptional collection of furniture, decorative arts, and historical artifacts that bring centuries of Portuguese royal life to vivid reality.
description.history: The current palace emerges from many royal buildings constructed, added, and adapted over centuries. The first building was likely constructed around the 10th or 11th century when Sintra was under Moorish rule. King João I ordered major renovations in the late 14th and early 15th centuries, adding the distinctive chimneys and many of the rooms visitors see today. King Manuel I continued expansions in the early 16th century. The palace served as a summer residence for Portuguese royalty until the 19th century and survived the devastating 1755 earthquake that destroyed much of Lisbon.
description.significance: As the only palace spanning the entire history of Portugal, it serves as a guardian of memories and witness to defining episodes in Portuguese history. The palace is part of the Cultural Landscape of Sintra, designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and represents an exceptional testimony to royal life across nearly a millennium.

directions.general: Located in the historic center of Sintra village, the palace is easily identifiable by its two massive conical chimneys
directions.fromCruisePort: From Lisbon cruise port, take train from Rossio or Oriente station to Sintra (40 minutes), then walk 10 minutes uphill or take bus 434/435
directions.publicTransport: Train from Lisbon (Rossio, Oriente, or Entrecampos stations) to Sintra station (30-40 minutes). From Sintra station, walk 10-15 minutes uphill or take Scotturb buses 434 or 435 directly to the palace
directions.parking: Limited parking in historic center. Use designated car parks and walk or take public transport to the palace

seasonal.notes: Ticket office closed from 12:00 to 13:00. Automatic ticket vending machines available

admissionPrices.notes: 15% discount when purchasing online. Children 0-5 free. Youth 6-17 years. Seniors 65+. Family ticket covers 2 adults + 2 youth. Gardens are free to enter

visitingInformation.bestTimeToVisit: Early morning (9:30-11:00) or late afternoon to avoid peak crowds. Weekdays are quieter than weekends
visitingInformation.adviceForVisitors: Purchase tickets online for 15% discount and to skip queues. Sintra can be visited year-round but mornings tend to be fresher. Wear comfortable shoes for walking through multiple rooms and levels. Consider a combined ticket to visit multiple Sintra palaces. Allow a full day to explore Sintra's multiple attractions

cruisePassengerInfo.timeNeededFromPort: Half day minimum (4-5 hours including train travel from Lisbon)
cruisePassengerInfo.accessibility: Moderate - requires train journey from Lisbon (40 minutes) plus short walk or bus from Sintra station
tips: Start very early to visit multiple Sintra attractions in one day
Buy train tickets from Lisbon in advance during peak season
Consider purchasing Parks of Sintra combo ticket for multiple palaces
Sintra is cooler than Lisbon - bring a light jacket
Combine with lunch in Sintra's charming historic center
Try the famous travesseiros pastries at Piriquita bakery
Take bus 434 tourist route to visit multiple sites efficiently

highlights: Two iconic 33-meter conical chimneys crowning the kitchen
Swan Room with 27 swans painted on the ceiling
Magpie Room featuring 136 magpies holding scrolls
Coats of Arms Room with spectacular domed ceiling
Extensive collection of 15th-16th century azulejo tiles
Golden Chamber with intricate coffered ceiling
Palace gardens with peacocks and historic trees
facilities: Gift shop with local crafts and souvenirs

accessibility.mobilityNotes: Ground floor and some rooms are accessible. Upper floors require stairs. Historic building with some narrow passages and uneven floors. Gardens are more accessible than interior
